results.title: We live by the river
results.creator_credit: Jack Howells, Richard Crawston and BBC Film Unit
results.brief_description: The atmosphere, the spirit and the pride of London, seen through the eyes of two young boys from the south side (right bank) of the River Thames. They set off one morning to see, for the first time, the more famous part of London, with its many historic buildings, its parks and shops, which lie on the opposite bank. The story is told through scenes and music only - no commentary. Photographed by Clifford Hornby.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jack Howells, Richard Crawston and BBC Film Unit

results.title: We lead the world
results.brief_description: The high incidence of tractor accidents in New Zealand and the safety precautions necessary with tractors. Proper handling of clutch and differential steering; need for guards on moving parts; keeping children away from tractors; need to know the country and take particular care on sloping ground; danger of driving a tractor with nobody near to help in case of accident.

results.title: We grew a frog
results.creator_credit: Nigel Rea, Peter Boulton and Boulton-Hawker Films
results.brief_description:
Records an activity in which children collect and rear frog spawn in a tank at their school. Covers each stage in the development of the frog, showing details not easily seen in a classroom aquarium.
Suitable for upper primary level.

results.title: We don't want to live on our knees
results.creator_credit: Julia Spark and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “History in action”.
On 2nd August 1968, Soviet planes and tanks invaded Czechoslovakia. The invasion came as a surprise because only two weeks before a meeting at Bratislava between Dubcek, Secretary of the Czech Communist Party and the entire Russian Politbureau appeared to have gone well. Why then was Czechoslovakia invaded, and why did the Russians fear the new freedoms which had taken place?

results.title: We don't make him special
results.creator_credit: Peter Brighton, Joan Reidy, Marjorie Fisher and I E A
results.brief_description: The story of the integration into life’s normal activities of a Down’s syndrome child as related by his mother. The acceptance of the child into the school community is effectively portrayed enabling the program to be utilised by a school contemplating the integration of disabled students. A positive program that supports the belief that the whole community benefits from the integration of disabled people into society.

results.title: We can work it out (NP)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Secretary and Her Boss”.
Secretary (Adrienne Posta) and her boss (John Cleese) try to resolve the problems presented in the unsatisfactory manner in which they both handle visitors, telephone calls and dictation.
FOR USE ONLY IN A DOMESTIC SITUATION OR FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES ONLY.

results.title: We can't stand still can we?
results.creator_credit: Ken McCready, Roman Bittman and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: This film is about the urban renewal plan drawn up by the town council of High River, Alberta. It saved the town, and could save many others across Canada.

results.title: We can't afford to be casual about child care (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Anne Smith, Michael Milan and Audio Visual Learning Centre, University of Otago
results.brief_description: Child care is discussed by Dr. Bettye Caldwell from the University of Arkansas and Pat Hubbard, director of the Dunedin community child care centre. They discuss whether child care damages mother-child attachment, the importance of an optimal environment for children in early years, the particular qualities and nature of good child care, and the difficulty in financing it

results.title: We call them killers
results.creator_credit: Tom Shandel, Peter Jones and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: A rare opportunity to observe two killer whales, Haida and Chimo, kept at the time of filming at the Victoria Sealand of the Pacific Aquarium. Far from any show of ferocity, the huge mammals display a sense of fun and rapport with their trainers, especially during their performances for the public. Dr. Paul Spong, noted cetologist, describes his attempts at inter-species communication. Musician Paul Horn captivates Haida with the sounds of his flute.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tom Shandel, Peter Jones and ONF | NFB

results.title: We are one
results.brief_description:
A rhythmic montage-in-motion of children around the world - playing, running, dancing, crying, laughing, eating - with touching contrasts and funny similarities. The message is universal love and hope: modern skills give mankind the chance to make this one world.
Based on the NHK production by Akira Takasaka and Kuniji Kodama.
